questions.text: What is the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding?
questions.solution:
The most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding is hemophilia A. It is caused by mutations in factor VIII, an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade.

Note: von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with the following finding after a trivial fall. His lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Platelet count - 4,00,000 /μL

Bleeding time - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - prolonged
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. 

Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively.

Clinical features of hemophilia:

  • Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities
  • Recurrent bleeding
  • Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor

It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT.

Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was found to have excessive bleeding following tooth extraction. Lab investigations revealed prolonged aPTT, decreased serum factor VIII levels and normal VwF activity. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. Hence, it affects mainly males and homozygous females.

Hemophilia B is also inherited as X-linked recessive trait. 

Hemophilia C is inherited as an autosomal-recessive trait.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about hemophilia?

choices.text: Hemophilia A in female may indicate unfavourable lyonization
Hemophilia A can occur without any family history

questions.solution:
Hemophilia A and B mostly affect males, but rarely can affect females also.

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, affecting mainly males and homozygous females. Rarely, excessive bleeding occurs in heterozygous females. It is due to the inactivation of the X chromosome bearing the normal factor VIII allele by chance in most cells (unfavourable lyonization). About 30% of patients have no family history and the disorder is caused due to new mutations.

Hemophilia B is inherited as X-linked recessive trait. There is a deficiency of factor IX.

Hemophilia C is an autosomal-recessive condition and hence can occur in females. There is a deficiency of factor XI.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with easy bruising was diagnosed to have moderate hemophilia A. What will be the percentage of normal factor VIII in her?
questions.solution:
Patients with moderate hemophilia A have 2% - 5% of normal levels of factor VIII.

The clinical manifestations of Hemophilia A vary in severity, corresponding to the level of factor VIII present. They can be classified as: 

Severity Levels of factor VIII
Mild 6-50%
Moderate 2-5%
Severe <1%

questions.text:
Which of the following lab findings are seen in patients with hemophilia A?
Options Platelet count Bleeding time PT aPTT
1 Normal Normal Normal Increased
2 Decreased Increased  Normal Normal
3 Normal  Increased Normal Increased
4 Decreased Increased Increased Increased
questions.solution:
Patients with hemophilia A have:

  • Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) - intrinsic pathway abnormality
  • Normal prothrombin time (PT) 
  • Normal bleeding time
  • Normal platelet count

questions.text:
A newborn baby develops severe umbilical cord bleeding soon after birth. Lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Bleeding time - normal

Platelet count - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - normal

TT - normal

Urea lysis test - positive
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of factor XIII deficiency. A positive urea lysis test confirms the diagnosis.

Factor XIII is also known as clot-stabilizing factor that converts unstable fibrin clot into a stable clot. Its deficiency typically presents as excessive umbilical cord bleeding in the newborn.

Laboratory findings in this condition are:

  • Normal levels of bleeding time (BT), platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and thrombin time (TT)
  • Positive urea lysis test - confirmatory test which demonstrates lysis of clot by hyperosmolar urea in affected individuals

The parameters for the given diseases:

Condition PT aPTT BT TT Platelet count Urea lysis test 
Vitamin K deficiency increased increased increased normal/increased normal/decreased negative
Von Willebrand disease normal normal/increased increased normal normal negative
Hemorrhagic disease of newborn increased increased increased normal/increased normal/decreased negative
Factor XIII deficiency normal normal normal normal normal positive

questions.text:
A Hemogram of a 23-year-old patient with a bleeding disorder is given below. Which of the following would you use to differentiate between heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and afibrinogenemia in this patient?

Platelet count - 3,23,000 /μL

PT - elevated

aPTT - elevated

TT - elevated
questions.solution:
Reptilase is a thrombin agonist which is used to differentiate heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) and afibrinogenemia. It is resistant to the action of heparin.

The differential diagnosis for normal platelet count with elevated PT, aPTT and TT are HIT and afibrinogenemia. After adding reptilase, if the TT is corrected, it points to HIT. In afibrinogenemia, since there is an absence of fibrin, there is no change in the TT.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child was diagnosed to have Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. What is this condition associated with?
questions.solution:
Kasabach–Merritt syndrome is associated with DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation). This syndrome is characterised by the following features:

  • Rapidly growing vascular tumour
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia
  • Consumptive coagulopathy

An unusual form of DIC occurs in association with giant hemangiomas. In this type, stasis and recurrent trauma to the fragile blood vessels cause thrombi to form within the neoplasm.

The image given below shows a reddish-blue lesion covering the lower part of the abdomen. It is a caverno-capillary haemangioma seen in Kasabach–Merritt syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo?
questions.solution:
Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo.

Unlike the clotting cascade in the lab (in vitro), the cascade in the body (in vivo) differs slightly - as tissue factor (TF) is the major initiator of the cascade. The TF/VIIa complex is the most important activator of factor IX and factor IXa/factor VIIIa complex is the most important activator of factor X. Factor V is involved in both the pathways as shown in the image below.

The coagulation cascade in the laboratory:

  • Extrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube):  Tissue factor → Factor VII → Factor X.
  • Intrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Factor XII →  Factor XI → Factor IX → Factor X 

Laboratory methods to initiate clotting include:

  • Intrinsic pathway - adding phospholipids, calcium, and either a negatively charged substance such as glass beads
  • Extrinsic pathway - a source of tissue factor

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

Causes of prolonged PT:

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

Causes of prolonged APTT:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: At what temperature should you store the sample for antiphospholipid antibody factor assays?
questions.solution:
The sample for antiphospholipid antibody assay must be stored at <4°.

Samples for coagulation studies should be stored always at room temperature (20 to 25 degrees).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the casualty with severe bleeding following a road traffic accident. He is a known cardiac disease patient on anticoagulant therapy.  As an intern, you were asked to collect blood for coagulation studies. Which colour vacutainer will you pick?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.

The benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate.

Other anticoagulants are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V and VIII) are unstable in oxalate (grey), whereas heparin (green) and EDTA (lavender) directly inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. Also, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin (green).

The image given below shows colour coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses.

Note: Heparin is used for blood sample collection for electrolyte estimation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the color of vacutainer containing sodium fluoride as a content?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride is present in the grey coloured tube.

Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis. Hence, is used for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway?
questions.solution:
Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis.

It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages are:

  • Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis
  • Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing)
  • Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding
  • Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
  • Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation
  • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability
